#Text=Thomas Legh ( lawyer )
#Text=For those of the same or similar names , see Thomas Leigh ( disambiguation ) .
#Text=Sir Thomas Leigh or Legh ( ?1511-1545 ) was an English jurist and diplomat , who played a key role as agent of Henry VIII and Thomas Cromwell in the Dissolution of the Monasteries . [ 1 ] [ 2 ]
#Text=Life

#Text=The younger son of John Leigh , lord of the manor of Frizington , Cumberland , he was a cousin of Bishop Rowland Leigh ( or Lee ) , scions of the ancient Leigh family of West Hall , High Legh , Cheshire .
#Text=Leigh was educated at Eton College before entering King 's College , Cambridge proceeding LLB in 1527 , and LLD in 1531 . [ 3 ]
#Text=He was called to the Bar 7 October 1531 .
#Text=In December 1532 he was appointed ambassador to the King of Denmark ; Imperial Ambassador Eustace Chapuys was unimpressed with Dr Leigh at this time .
#Text=He was recalled from Denmark in March 1533 , then being employed in 1533 by his cousin the bishop .

#Text=He cited Catherine of Aragon to appear before Thomas Cranmer and hear the final divorce sentence in 1533 , and in the same year also conducted an inquiry at Rievaulx Abbey which led to the resignation of the abbot .
#Text=In January 1533-4 he was sent on another embassy to the Low Countries , passing through Antwerp and Lübeck .
#Text=He returned to England in April , went again to Hamburg in May , and must have returned once more in the summer .
#Text=On 4 June 1535 Richard Layton wrote to Cromwell recommending Leigh and himself to be Visitors of the northern religious houses .
#Text=Leigh , however , was first sent with Sir John Price ( or ap Rice ) ; in July 1535 they went to Worcester , and then visited , 3 July Malvern , 20 August
#Text=Lacock Abbey ( after Malmesbury , Bradstock , and Stanley ) , 23 August
#Text=Bruton Abbey , 3 September Wilton , 11 September Wherwell , 24 September Witney , 25 September Reading , 29 September Haliwell , 17 October Royston , and 19 October Walden .
#Text=Leigh made a large profit out of the visitation , and complaints of his conduct were numerous .
#Text=Leigh was always accompanied by fourteen men in livery and his brother , all of whom had to be rewarded .
#Text=His style was flamboyant , and Cromwell found fault with him .
#Text=Sir John ap Rice , who thought his treatment of the monks needlessly severe , describes his insolence .
#Text=To Leigh 's suggestion was due the suspension of the bishops ' authority during the visitation .
#Text=At Cambridge

#Text=Leigh 's changes were few ; he ordered ( 22 October 1535 ) the charters to be sent up to London with a rental of the university possessions , tried to pacify the strife among the nations , and established a lecture in divinity .
#Text=Thomas Goodrich , Bishop of Ely , wrote approvingly of his proceedings .

#Text=Leigh went on to Bury , 4 November ; Westacre , 11 November , after West Dereham ; Norwich , 19 November ; Ipswich , 27 November ; and meeting Richard Layton at Lichfield at Christmas 1535 he proceeded with him to the northern visitation .
#Text=The mastership of Sherburn Hospital in Durham was granted to Leigh on 14 September 1535 .

#Text=He also acquired the advowson of Birmingham from Gisborough Priory in March 1536 ; Calder Abbey in Cumberland was granted to him in 1539 , and Nostell Priory in Yorkshire , with its cell at Stowkirke , in 1539-40. A letter of May 1536 to Johannes Aepinus shows that he was acquainted with Melanchthon and Oldendorpius .
#Text=In 1536 he assisted at the trial of Anne Boleyn .

#Text=During the Pilgrimage of Grace in 1536 he was as unpopular as his colleague Layton ; they sang ballads about him and Leigh as one of the three L 's ( Richard Layton , dean of York and John Longland , bishop of Lincoln , were the other two )
#Text=one ballad ; and they hanged his cook .
#Text=He meanwhile was busy taking money to the forces , and when the rebellion was over he tried the prisoners .
#Text=In August 1536 he had made a tour through the Midlands archdeaconries of Coventry and Stafford , and was much distressed by the open adultery of the country gentlemen .
#Text=He married in 1536 , and was reprimanded by his friends for not informing them of it . [ 4 ]
#Text=Some time in the early part of 1537 he became a master in chancery , and throughout 1538 , 1539 , and 1540 he was engaged in suppressing religious houses .
#Text=In 1543 Leigh went from York to Canterbury to investigate the plot against Thomas Cranmer .
#Text=He was knighted at Leith by the Earl of Hertford , on 11 May 1544 , seemingly on the Scottish expedition .
#Text=Leigh was a Member ( MP ) of the Parliament of England for Hindon in 1536 and for Wilton in 1545 . [ 5 ]
#Text=He died 25 November 1545 , [ 3 ] and was buried at St. Leonard 's , Shoreditch , London , where a tomb with a rhyming inscription was erected in his memory .
#Text=Marriage
#Text=His widow Dame Joanna ( née Cotton ) remarried Sir Thomas Chaloner , and died 11 January 1557 .
#Text=Their only child , Catherine Leigh , married James Blount , 6th Baron Mountjoy , and had issue including Charles Blount , 1st Earl of Devonshire .
